choices.D: Highlighting of row access policy usage
choices.E: Identification of who has read data
choices.B: Identification of which roles have been used

discussion.content:

Selected Answer: AE
A
E


C - no, use this instead: https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/account-usage/network_policies
B - I would probably use QUERY_HISTORY for that instead https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/account-usage/query_history
D - I would use this instead: ROW_ACCESS_POLICIES https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/account-usage/row_access_policies

Selected Answer: DE
Specifies the DDL operation on a database, schema, table, view, and column. These operations also include statements that specify a row access policy on a table or view, a masking policy on a column, and tag updates (e.g. set a tag, change a tag value) on the object or column.

Selected Answer: DE
No mention of roles into the columns of the view into the user document

The benefits of using the ACCESS_HISTORY view in the Snowflake database include:

Identification of who has read data
Tracking of which roles have been used
Highlighting of row access policy usage
By using the ACCESS_HISTORY view, organizations can get a better understanding of who has access to what data within their Snowflake environment, and ensure that data is being accessed and used in an appropriate manner.

Selected Answer: A
Access history in Snowflake provides the following benefits pertaining to read and write operations:

Data discovery
Discover unused data to determine whether to archive or delete the data.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements describes a benefit of Snowflakeâs separation of compute and storage? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
correct

Selected Answer: BC
Both can be managed saperately as per business needs. They are not bounded, this is what cloud is for

Selected Answer: BC
For Snowflake, this is not an issue. You can grow and shrink the environment dynamically. The data storage grows and shrinks as you add or remove data, while the compute nodes can be ramped up or down, or turned off, as you require. You are not forced to pay for capacity up front, or kick other workloads off, or plan downtimes when ramping up your data warehouse capacity. That is the promise of cloud. This is why Snowflake is the real elastic Data Warehouse as a Service.
Need more help on this as D is confusing me! I guess B and C are correct, but D also seems ok ?

choices.C: Compute can be scaled up or down without the requirement to add more storage.
choices.A: Growth of storage and compute are tightly coupled.
choices.D: Compute and storage can be scaled together.
choices.E: Use of storage avoids disk spilling.
choices.B: Storage expands without the requirement to add more compute.
